questions.prompt: Is there a target start date for field installation activities?
What is the anticipated duration of the installation phase?
Will the project be executed in multiple phases (e.g., pilot, rollout, zones)?
questions.helperText: Best practice: use a short pilot to validate integrations, billing, and customer outreach, then transition directly into full deployment without a gap in work to avoid contractor demobilization costs.

questions.prompt: Are there any labor compliance or workforce requirements applicable to this project?
questions.helperText: Best practice: disclose all labor compliance requirements and funding sources up front (prevailing wage / Davis-Bacon / PLA / union), because labor is a major driver of installation pricing.

questions.prompt: Are there any state or local licensing requirements for contractors performing meter installation work?
questions.helperText: Best practice: clearly identify all required state, county, or municipal licenses up front so only qualified contractors bid the project and award delays are avoided.

questions.prompt: Are there specific insurance requirements beyond standard utility contractor coverage?
questions.helperText: Best practice: clearly state standard insurance requirements up front and identify any additional coverage so contractors can confirm compliance and price risk appropriately.

questions.prompt: Are there any small business, MBE/WBE, DBE, or similar participation requirements?
questions.helperText: Best practice: clearly disclose any MBE/WBE/DBE or similar participation requirements so contractors understand bid scoring criteria, subcontracting expectations, and potential cost impacts.

questions.prompt: What existing meter reading system is currently in place for the meters in scope (to be removed/replaced)?
questions.helperText: Installation and integration requirements vary significantly based on whether the current environment is direct read, AMR, or AMI. Provide what you know so bidders can plan compatibility, data handling, and removal steps correctly.

questions.prompt: Legacy vendor/platform details (recommended): What make/model(s) of endpoints and reading system are in use today?
questions.helperText: Best practice: list vendors/platforms and endpoint models so bidders can confirm compatibility and plan transition steps.

questions.prompt: What is the predominant material or construction of the existing water meters to be removed?
questions.helperText: Understanding meter material helps bidders plan removal, recycling, and disposal. Material type can affect recycling value, handling requirements, and cost assumptions.

questions.prompt: Will removal of existing endpoints involve lithium or other regulated batteries requiring special disposal or recycling?
questions.helperText: Existing AMI endpoints often contain lithium batteries that require regulated recycling or disposal. Clarifying scope and responsibility helps avoid unexpected disposal cost.

questions.prompt: Will the utility provide service-level or asset-level data to support installation planning?
questions.helperText: Service-level and asset-level data allows contractors to plan materials, load trucks appropriately, and reduce failed installations. The completeness and reliability of this data directly affects productivity, cost, and whether field surveys may be required.

questions.prompt: If data is provided, which of the following elements are included? (Select all that apply)
questions.helperText: The specific data elements provided determine how accurately contractors can plan materials, routes, and crew workflows. Missing elements may require field validation or conservative assumptions.

questions.prompt: How should existing service-level or asset-level data be relied upon for installation planning and deployment?
options: Utility-provided data should be assumed accurate and used for planning
Utility-provided data is informational only and requires field validation
Data will be refined or validated prior to deployment (survey or prep phase)
questions.helperText:
Installation contractors base pricing and staffing on assumed efficiency derived from planning data.

If utility-provided data is used for planning and later determined to be inaccurate or incomplete, this may result in reduced productivity, additional site visits, or rework. These conditions typically lead to one of the following outcomes:
- Change orders or scope adjustments requested by the contractor, or
- Contingency pricing built into the contractorâ€™s bid to absorb uncertainty.

If data accuracy is uncertain, upfront validation or a targeted field survey is often recommended to reduce cost and schedule risk and avoid inflated pricing or post-award changes.

questions.prompt: How frequently will service-level or asset-level data be updated or refreshed during the project?
options: Frequent or ongoing updates (e.g., daily or near real-time)
questions.helperText:
Data update frequency affects installation planning accuracy, integration effort, and overall project efficiency.

Short-duration projects or small meter counts may be successfully managed with a one-time or periodic data file. Longer-duration projects are more likely to experience customer turnover, routine maintenance changes, and meter activity that require more frequent updates.

More frequent updates can improve accuracy but may increase integration complexity or cost depending on utility systems and contractor capabilities.

questions.prompt: How will service-level or asset-level data be exchanged between the utility and the installation contractor during the project?
options: Spreadsheet or manual file exchange (e.g., Excel)
questions.helperText:
The data exchange method affects integration cost, setup effort, and ongoing coordination between the utility and the installation contractor.

More automated approaches can improve efficiency but often require greater upfront technical effort. Simpler methods may be easier to manage for smaller or less technically resourced utilities but can increase manual effort or risk of delay.

questions.prompt: Will utility-provided data specify the required work type at each service location (e.g., meter change, endpoint-only, register-only)?
options: Yes â€” work type will be specified and may change over time
Yes â€” work type will be specified and remain fixed
No â€” contractor determines work scope in the field
questions.helperText:
Some utilities provide data files that not only identify service locations but also specify the exact work to be performed at each location.

While this can reduce discovery effort or survey requirements, it may increase integration complexity and affect contractor planning efficiency, particularly if work types change during the project.

questions.prompt: When data discrepancies or system exceptions are identified during or after installation, how should reconciliation and corrective actions be handled?
options: Contractor corrects data and resubmits through defined process
Contractor flags issue; utility reviews, corrects, and reissues data
Bidirectional exception reporting with defined reconciliation workflow
Formal exception and approval workflow required before proceeding
questions.helperText:
Data discrepancies may originate from field conditions, data entry errors, or system validation rules.

In mature deployments, exceptions may generate automated reports, reconciliation tasks, or action-required workflows on either the contractor or utility side.

questions.prompt: Will a pre-deployment field survey or audit be required to validate asset data, site conditions, or work scope prior to installation?
options: Yes â€” full survey required before installation
Yes â€” limited survey (specific elements only)
No â€” rely on existing data; contractor proceeds
Survey to be proposed as an optional add-alternate
questions.helperText:
Field surveys are commonly used to validate data accuracy, confirm site conditions, and reduce execution risk.

Certain AMI systems may impose specific requirements related to pit or vault conditions, including lid size, material, condition, and whether drilling, cutting, or lid replacement is required.

These factors should be considered when determining the appropriate level of survey needed.

questions.prompt: If a pre-deployment survey or audit is performed, who will be responsible for executing it and funding it?
options: Utility performs and funds the survey
questions.helperText:
Survey execution and funding directly affect accountability for data accuracy, material planning, and change order risk.

The party performing the survey is typically best positioned to validate field conditions, determine material needs, and manage downstream execution risk.

questions.prompt: What customer notification or outreach activities are required? (Select all that apply)
questions.helperText: Best practice: Use mailers/postcards for pre-install notification when required, and use a post-install door hanger to confirm the work performed, provide flushing instructions, and provide contact information. Door hangers used as advance notice typically add cost because they require an extra site visit.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for customer outreach materials and distribution / scheduling communications?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Indoor access/scheduling outreach should be contractor-led so the contractor can control sequencing, call center load, and appointment booking. For pit-set work, utility-led pre-notification can be acceptable if appointments are not required.

questions.prompt: Are outreach materials required in languages other than English?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Identify language requirements up front so bidders can plan translation, printing, and call-center staffing accordingly.

questions.prompt: Will the contractor be required to provide customer support or a call center for PIT-set installations?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Inside-set programs require contractor call center + dispatch. This question is primarily to confirm whether similar requirements apply to pit-set work (often limited to day-of-install issues).

questions.prompt: Are there any additional leave-behind materials required after an installation (beyond a standard door hanger)?
questions.helperText: Best practice: A post-install door hanger is standard and cost-effective. If additional materials are required, the utility should provide approved content; the contractor may provide examples, but final approval should be utility-controlled prior to printing.

questions.prompt: If the contractor is distributing outreach or leave-behind materials, who provides the final approved content?
options: Contractor drafts; utility approves final content
Contractor provides final content (utility accepts as-is)
questions.helperText: Best practice: The contractor can provide draft templates, but the utility should approve final content before printing and distribution to avoid customer issues and ensure regulatory/communications alignment.

questions.prompt: If access cannot be obtained or a location cannot be completed, what enforcement or escalation mechanisms may be used to achieve full program completion?
options: Utility fee / enforcement process may be used
Service shutoff may be used (where allowed)
Return to utility (RTU) after defined attempts
questions.helperText: Best practice: Define thresholds and escalation paths up front. Without a mechanism to drive access and completion, completion rates commonly plateau and the program may stall.

questions.prompt: How should the program treat unresolved locations for workflow closure purposes (e.g., no-response, refusal, access issues)?
options: Returned to utility after defined attempts
Considered complete for contractor scope after defined threshold
questions.helperText: Best practice: Define a clear threshold and a consistent disposition (UIR/RTU) so crews can maintain productivity and the program can progress without endless revisits.

questions.prompt: How should unsuccessful attempts or unresolved locations be treated commercially (payment / revisits / closeout)?
options: Pay for unsuccessful attempts / return visits (defined rate)
Pay after defined attempt threshold even if not completed (documented RTU/UIR)
questions.helperText: Best practice: Align payment rules with the notification and enforcement plan. If payment is completion-only but access enforcement is weak, contractors will add contingency pricing or disputes will occur.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for storage and custody of meters, endpoints, lids, and installation materials?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Assign clear custody and insurance responsibility to avoid disputes over loss, theft, or damage.

questions.prompt: Will there be a centralized warehouse or staging location available for this project?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Defined staging improves productivity, accountability, and deployment pacing.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for disposal, recycling, or salvage of removed materials?
options: Materials will be returned to utility inventory
questions.helperText: Best practice: Clearly define disposal responsibility to avoid regulatory exposure and post-award disputes.

questions.prompt: Will lithium batteries or electronic components require special handling, transport, or recycling?
options: Yes â€” both lithium batteries and electronic components
questions.helperText: Best practice: Identify special handling early to comply with DOT, EPA, and state regulations.

questions.prompt: Who is responsible for material loss, theft, or damage while materials are in storage or transit?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Align responsibility with custody and insurance coverage to avoid disputes.

questions.prompt: Will materials be delivered in bulk or phased to align with deployment?
options: Phased delivery aligned to deployment schedule
questions.helperText: Best practice: Material delivery strategy directly affects contractor risk pricing, crew efficiency, and schedule certainty.

questions.prompt: Are there any site-specific or regulatory constraints related to material storage or disposal?
questions.helperText: Best practice: Early identification of constraints reduces compliance risk and change orders.
